items.synopsis: Mitchell was in and out of group homes for 10 years. His parents became concerned when he began begging not to go.

title.children: Mitchell's medication was prescribed for repeated seizures. His parents suspect his group home used it to control him

image.altText: Ukrainian soldier bends over and covers ears as a mortar is fired.

title.children: Ukraine says it is repelling Russian attacks in Bakhmut, as US says it over-valued weapons aid

image.altText: Doctor Ken Elliott smiles

items.synopsis: Australian doctor Kenneth Elliott is released "safe and well" after being kidnapped in Burkina Faso in 2016 by a group believed to have links to al Qaeda, with Foreign Minister Penny Wong saying the 88-year-old has been reunited with his family.

title.children: Australian doctor kidnapped by West African militant group released after seven years

image.altText: Police in hi-vos vests search through rubbish.

items.synopsis: Police tell the ABC the search of the rubbish tip has been called off because waste is decomposing at a rate faster than predicted.

title.children: Police say it's unlikely they'll ever find the body of missing Brisbane woman Lesley Trotter

image.altText: A house with a veranda and a for lease sign outside, leaning against wall

image.altText: A middle-aged white man with grey hair and glasses wearing a suit speaks in a public place with a cityscape behind him.

items.synopsis: Like Anthony Albanese, Tanya Plibersek is pragmatic, but probably hasn't moved quite so far to the centre as he has. If she were running things, would this Labor government have a more radical tinge, Michelle Grattan asks.

title.children: As Albanese celebrates a year in office it's hard not to wonder what might have been

image.altText: a man wearing a white and maroon polo standing in a park

items.synopsis: Mayor Robbie Sands says he believes the funeral home sent the wrong body for the burial six weeks ago.

title.children: Families 'hurting and suffering' after Aboriginal elder mistakenly buried in wrong grave

image.altText: Pile of rubbish at a house, including old mattresses, bikes, boxes and bottles.

items.synopsis: International students say they are being blamed for the rental crisis, but they're also facing housing stress and exploitation. Their horror stories are being shared back home and other students are now ditching plans to come to Australia.

title.children: Facing housing horrors, international students say they were misled about the cost of living in Australia

image.altText: Vincent Lingiari addresses media

items.synopsis: 'No' campaign leaders Warren Mundine and Jacinta Nampijinpa Price have both claimed Indigenous land rights activist Vincent Lingiari's grandson opposed the Voice. Was that actually correct?

title.children: 'I'm not his grandson': How the 'No' campaign misled using Vincent Lingiari's name

image.altText: Noel Pearson, wearing a brown hat, speaks at a lectern at a Garma Festival in north-east Arnhem Land.

title.children: Noel Pearson swipes fellow campaigner Mick Gooda, who says Voice to Parliament is losing support

image.altText: Flames rising out of a building with several firetrucks lined outside.

image.altText: An elderly woman in a church

items.synopsis: The use of a taser against 95-year-old Clare Nowland raises concerns about restraint and the use of force in aged care facilities, advocates say, as homicide squad investigators are called in to investigate.

title.children: Job of officer who tasered 95yo under review as disability advocates call for accountability

image.altText: A black, orange and white graphic that reads Barely Legal in big letters

items.synopsis: An Australian beer named Barely Legal, which uses a label design similar to that of the world's biggest pornography website, is withdrawn on the eve of a leading craft beer festival after the brewer acknowledged it "conveyed implications that were offensive".

title.children: 'Barely Legal' beer sparks backlash amid claims of sexism

image.altText: Jarome Luai reaches out to touch judge Chris Sutton to apologise for pushing him during an NRL match.

items.synopsis: A push to the back of touch judge Chris Sutton got the attention of commentators, but Penrith star Jarome Luai escapse with a fine rather than a suspension ahead of State of Origin selection.

title.children: Jarome Luai avoids ban for pushing touch judge ahead of Origin selection

image.altText: Composite image of drag queen Ashley Madison and movie character Mrs Doubtfire

items.synopsis: Characters like Mrs Doubtfire and Dame Edna have generated widespread affection. But drag queens say this love only goes so far.

title.children: 'Nothing to do with drag, everything with being queer': Drag queen calls out cancellation of rainbow story time

image.altText: An elderly woman leans in to blow out candles on her birthday cake

items.synopsis: The son of Gloria Shea, who suffered from emphysema and was reliant on life support equipment when the power cut off to her Dubbo home, wants energy companies to improve their safety measures.

title.children: Family seeks urgent changes to home life support after great-grandmother dies during power cut

image.altText: A little boy sits in a little car next to his brother while his mother stands in the background holding a baby

items.synopsis: Hundreds of Australian families are on long waitlists to see a paediatrician and specialists say an overhaul is urgently needed.

title.children: Jessica Harris says it's 'impossible to get pediatric care for her son and specialists say an 18-month wait is not unusual

image.altText: Two US officials stand guard at a border crossing. A group of migrants stand behind a fence.

items.synopsis: An 8-year-old girl from Panama has died in US Border Patrol custody, Customs and Border Protection says.

title.children: Girl, 8, dies in US Border Patrol custody, officials confirm

image.altText: A small, concrete house.

items.synopsis: Researchers are taking on the challenges of waste and housing affordability, by substituting sand for used nappies in concrete mortar. They've even built a house with the product.

title.children: House made from recycled nappies solves two problems at once, researchers say

image.altText: Ron DeSantis gesticulates in front of an American flag

items.synopsis: The decision follows a year of attacks from Florida Governor Ron DeSantis and the legislature, with Disney filing a First Amendment lawsuit against him last month.

title.children: Disney scraps Florida plans as political opponents criticise presidential hopeful

image.altText: Bianca Spender

items.synopsis: Local designers have been showing off their work at Australian Fashion Week — but behind the scenes, a new scheme is being rolled out to make the fashion industry more sustainable.

title.children: How the Australian fashion industry plans to tackle its 'big clothing waste problem'

image.altText: A close-up shot of the wall of an office, with the sign "World Anti-Doping Agency"

items.synopsis: The World Anti-Doping Agency updates the success of its investigation into the infamous Moscow laboratory at the centre of institutionalised Russian doping, saying 200-plus athletes have been sanctioned from data collected.

title.children: WADA 'Operation LIMS' passes 200 Russian athletes sanctioned for doping, more to come

image.altText: Two Korean women in face masks walk through a busy Seoul laneway

items.synopsis: The South Korean government is offering cash incentives to boost its record low fertility rate. But these experts say it ignores the real issues.

title.children: South Korean women have a lot to feel angry about. Is that why the country's fertility rate ranks lowest in the world?

image.altText: An ASX board shot by John Gunn in Deccember 2022.

items.synopsis: Australia's share market has opened higher this morning, after a small rally on Wall Street overnight.

title.children: ASX opens higher, US debt ceiling negotiations continue

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some deeply concerning data from CBA should give the Reserve Bank even more pause for thought ahead of its June meeting, following weak jobs data and contained wages growth. Look at this graph: What it's showing you is that, even before this month's 0.25 percentage point rate rise, the interest charged on CBA customers' home loans had risen more than 50%. It also also showing you that their scheduled repayments — the money actually coming out of their account each month — had risen less than 20 per cent up to April. The scary thing? Over the next few months that blue line has to move much closer to the red line. This shows most mortgage customers are yet to feel anywhere near the full impact of the rate rises that have already happened. Why? Because there is roughly a three month lag between when an RBA rate rise happens and when the higher minimum repayment amount is passed through to the customer. And this is even before the full impact of the fixed rate mortgage cliff hits. CBA's internal data shows last month was the first big step up in fixed loans rolling off onto variable rates. All of these customers are facing interest rates that have more than doubled, in many cases tripled, since they took out their fixed loans. And CBA economist Stephen Wu says those customers will also have a lag between when their fixed loan expires until their scheduled repayments rise. "At CBA there is generally a lag of around a few months between when a fixed term loan expires and when the required mortgage repayment steps up," he explained. It's a reality check as to why the RBA needs to be very careful in raising rates further until it sees the effect of the hikes it's already implemented. Yesterday's jobs data is being interpreted by many economists as a likely turning point in the labour market, where unemployment turns higher.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA data shows full extent of interest rate lag

featuredLink.title: Economists predict jobs will 'likely' be lost as employment numbers reach a turning point

children.content: Some deeply concerning
data from CBA
should give the Reserve Bank even more pause for thought ahead of its June meeting, following
weak jobs data
and
contained wages growth
Look at this graph:
Interest charged versus scheduled repayments
(CBA)
What it's showing you is that, even before this month's 0.25 percentage point rate rise,
the interest charged on CBA customers' home loans had risen more than 50%
It also also showing you that their
scheduled repayments
— the money actually coming out of their account each month —
had risen less than 20 per cent
up to April.
The scary thing? Over the next few months that blue line has to move much closer to the red line.
This shows most mortgage customers are yet to feel anywhere near the full impact of the rate rises that have already happened.
Why? Because
there is roughly a three month lag between when an RBA rate rise happens and when the higher minimum repayment amount is passed through
to the customer.
And this is even before the full impact of the
fixed rate mortgage cliff
hits.
CBA's internal data shows last month was the first big step up in fixed loans rolling off onto variable rates.
CBA fixed loan expiry dates
(CBA)
All of these customers are facing interest rates that have more than doubled, in many cases tripled, since they took out their fixed loans.
And CBA economist Stephen Wu says those customers will also have a lag between when their fixed loan expires until their scheduled repayments rise.
"At CBA there is generally a lag of around a few months between when a fixed term loan expires and when the required mortgage repayment steps up," he explained.
It's a reality check as to why the RBA needs to be very careful in raising rates further until it sees the effect of the hikes it's already implemented.
Yesterday's jobs data is being interpreted by many economists as a likely turning point in the labour market, where unemployment turns higher.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reuters is reporting that the United States and the rest of the "Group of Seven" major economies will unveil new sanctions and export controls for Russia over its war against Ukraine. G7 leaders are gathering in Hiroshima on Friday and the invasion of Ukraine is high on the agenda: A U.S. official, speaking to reporters on Thursday ahead of the gathering, said the G7's latest efforts were aimed at disrupting Russia's ability to get materials it needs for the battlefield, close loopholes used to evade sanctions, further reduce international reliance on Russian energy, and narrow Moscow's access to the international financial system. "Our commitment to continue tightening the screws on Russia remains as strong as it was last year," the official said. The United States and its allies, including the European Union and Britain, have continued to ratchet up sanctions and export-control pressure on Russia since the invasion of Ukraine began in February 2022. Thousands of targets hit with sanctions by Washington so far have included Russian President Vladimir Putin, the financial sector and oligarchs. The latest U.S. sanctions package will include "extensively restricting categories of goods key to the battlefield" as well as preventing some 70 entities from Russia and third countries from receiving U.S. exports by adding them to the U.S. Commerce Department's blacklist. In addition, the United States will announce some 300 new sanctions against individuals, entities, vessels and aircraft targeting "financial facilitators", Russia's future energy extracting capabilities, and others across Europe, the Middle East and Asia helping to support the war. U.S. sanctions authorities would also be expanded to more sectors of the Russian economy. The U.S. official said Washington would take significant steps to align its actions closely with the EU and Britain to ensure that the G7 remained as coordinated as possible in response to "Russia's brutal actions".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More sanctions coming for Russia

children.content: Reuters is reporting that the United States and the rest of the "Group of Seven" major economies will unveil new sanctions and export controls for Russia over its war against Ukraine.
G7 leaders are gathering in Hiroshima on Friday and the invasion of Ukraine is high on the agenda:

A U.S. official, speaking to reporters on Thursday ahead of the gathering, said the G7's latest efforts were aimed at disrupting Russia's ability to get materials it needs for the battlefield, close loopholes used to evade sanctions, further reduce international reliance on Russian energy, and narrow Moscow's access to the international financial system.
"Our commitment to continue tightening the screws on Russia remains as strong as it was last year," the official said.

The United States and its allies, including the European Union and Britain, have continued to ratchet up sanctions and export-control pressure on Russia since the invasion of Ukraine began in February 2022. Thousands of targets hit with sanctions by Washington so far have included Russian President Vladimir Putin, the financial sector and oligarchs.

The latest U.S. sanctions package will include "extensively restricting categories of goods key to the battlefield" as well as preventing some 70 entities from Russia and third countries from receiving U.S. exports by adding them to the U.S. Commerce Department's blacklist.

In addition, the United States will announce some 300 new sanctions against individuals, entities, vessels and aircraft targeting "financial facilitators", Russia's future energy extracting capabilities, and others across Europe, the Middle East and Asia helping to support the war.
U.S. sanctions authorities would also be expanded to more sectors of the Russian economy.

The U.S. official said Washington would take significant steps to align its actions closely with the EU and Britain to ensure that the G7 remained as coordinated as possible in response to "Russia's brutal actions".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The fallout from the PwC scandal has a way to go yet. My colleague Peter Ryan says Liberal senator Andrew Bragg wants the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) to investigate the PwC tax leak. He's also severely criticised the decision to have Ziggy Switkowski leading the "independent review" of PwC in the wake of the controversy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC 'getting away with murder' says Liberal senator

children.content: The fallout from the PwC scandal has a way to go yet.
My colleague Peter Ryan says Liberal senator Andrew Bragg wants the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) to investigate the PwC tax leak.
He's also severely criticised the decision to have Ziggy Switkowski leading the "independent review" of PwC in the wake of the controversy.

image.altText: a cracked concrete driveway

title.children: 'Intergenerational' concrete scam travelling town-to-town across regional Australia

image.altText: Collage with blue arrow pointing up, photo cut out of Jim Chalmers, pile of coins and red background.

items.synopsis: Almost two-thirds of the top economists surveyed gave the budget an A or a B – up from the 40 per cent who gave top marks to Jim Chalmers's predecessor. But they were more critical when it came to inflation, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: More than 50 economists rate the budget from A to F

title.children: 'They will be hard to stop': Here's where each AFL club stands after nine rounds

image.altText: Man in cowboy hat stands outside westpac bank branch

items.synopsis: Regional communities home to some of Australia's most vital hubs of industry are being crippled by bank branch closures. A range of remedies have been proposed — but how viable are they?

title.children: More than 650 regional bank branches have closed since 2020. Here's how the problem could be solved
